bioghist.p: William Norman Brown (1892-1975) founded the South Asia Studies department at the University of Pennsylvania, the first in the United States, in 1948. From 1916 to 1919 Brown held the position of the Harrison Research Fellow at the Penn. After holding positions at Johns Hopkins and Prince of Wales College in Jammu, India, he returned to Penn to accept the chair of Sanskrit. He then steadily expanded South Asia educational offerings at the Penn, resulting in a full South Asia Studies department. He also organized the American Oriental Society in 1926.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of South Asia-related materials created or collected by William Norman Brown. Materials include: manuscripts of articles and addresses on Indian politics, religion, language, and art; photographs and negatives of Sanskrit texts and illustrated manuscripts; photographs of W. Norman Brown; notes on South Asian linguistics and vocabulary; and notes on miscellaneous South Asian subjects. There is a small amount of correspondence with colleagues and publishers, including some letters from Ananda K. Coomaraswamy. There are also manuscript and typescript drafts of articles on U.S. foreign policy, possibly by Charles Henry Burr, a 1891 copy of Poet-Lore including an article by Burr, and two photographs, possibly of Burr.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
